title: MD, PhD
biography: Thomas Earl Starzl (1926â€“2017) was an American physician widely recognized as the 'father of modern transplantation.' He performed the first human liver transplant in 1963 and the first successful liver transplant in 1967 at the University of Colorado. With over 2,200 publications, he was identified by the Institute for Scientific Information as the most cited author in the history of clinical medicine. Starzl pioneered the clinical use of cyclosporine (1982) and tacrolimus/FK506 (1989), immunosuppressive agents that revolutionized organ transplantation survival rates. He moved to the University of Pittsburgh in 1981, where he led the world's largest transplant program. His memoir, 'The Puzzle People' (1992), chronicles his surgical career and scientific discoveries.
techniquesInvented: Clinical Use of Cyclosporine in Transplantation (1982)

timeline.title: Earned MD and PhD from Northwestern University
First Human Liver Transplant
timeline.description: Performed the first-ever human liver transplant at the University of Colorado.

timeline.title: First Successful Liver Transplant
timeline.description: Achieved the first long-term liver transplant survival, proving the procedure viable.

timeline.title: Moved to University of Pittsburgh
timeline.description: Built the world's largest and busiest transplant program.

timeline.title: Pioneered Clinical Use of Cyclosporine
timeline.description: Introduced cyclosporine immunosuppression, dramatically improving graft survival.

timeline.title: Pioneered Tacrolimus (FK506)
timeline.description: Introduced FK506, which became the standard immunosuppressant in transplantation.

timeline.title: Passed Away
timeline.description: Left a legacy of 2,200+ publications and transformed the field of organ transplantation.
